Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Close reading analysis, how to do a lot of reading very quickly, how to annotate a text
How to do a close reading of the text -especially how to write reasonable arguments that are directly supported by the text.
I learned how to analyze, process, and understand complex and long texts.
I developed a new method of looking analytically at literature, especially by looking at individual phrases and words to understand themes in the text as a whole.
I learned how to write very well and how to analyze passages of Literature
An acquaintance with the major writers from Homer to Dante; ability to make connections across texts that informed and enriched my understanding of literary art.
I learned how to close-read, discuss, and write about texts of ancient literature.
A sense of how to evaluate and interpret a text.

This was easily my most influential course this semester! I became a dramatically better close reader and writer, and the opportunity to discuss major works of the Western Canon successively allowed me to appreciate several texts I was already familiar with in a new light and come to develop an appreciation for texts I had not read before taking this course. Discussing these works as part of a "canon" or tradition made it possible for me to think broadly about the nature of antiquity, the West (whatever that is), and literature more broadly.
Participation in seminar, critically thinking about the text, how to read a novel
Analyzing literature of multiple forms through close reading, close reading, close reading.

A lot of reading very fast is both a strength and a weakness. It's difficult to go in depth on all of it, but they do their best to go below the surface on every text. Some of the reading felt slightly out of place (like the Bible selections).
I like the way that the professor is accessible to the students.

Prof. Slanski is amazing and is the star of this course. I didn't like how fast-paced DS was, but that's in the nature of the program. Prof. Slanski did a great job finding depth among the breadth of what we did, so I'm grateful for that. We did have to skip so much of texts, making the readings feel like they weren't always worth it.

I thought we didnt spend enough time on some books like the Bible, but that is the nature of DS.  Otherwise, the course was fantastic and it was amazing to see how so many texts of the western canon cohere.
There's a bit too much reading to get done sometimes, and many times we never go over ALL of the reading in class

It is impossible to read deeply, and literature -- of all the disciplines (history, politics, philosophy) -- requires deep reading. One must follow the arc of a narrative and give oneself up to it. It is not simply an idea that a text offers. A work of literature gives content to one's impression of the world. How can this happen within a survey curriculum? I am not entirely sure. Perhaps a greater emphasis on the aesthetics of a work, as opposed to its canonical referentiality. If you read the canon chronologically (as you do in DS) these connections are not hard to find. But what needs to happen with a literature course is that the beauty of a work, its form, its images, are made visible, as opposed to simply its ideological importance, or the what happened in Chapter 24 summarizing approach. But perhaps this is an unfair criticism.
There wasnt much preparation for writing the first paper, which was a steep learning curve.

I thought this course was well-structured and paced; unlike my friends in other classes, I found the routine of Directed Studies refreshing and helpful, though I recognize that this class still posed a large workload. Sometimes there was simply too much to discuss in class, and I would have appreciated a way for us to engage with texts more thoroughly. I enjoyed the reading and writing assignments greatly, and Professor Slanski often encouraged us to take risks in our writing that allowed me to become a more well-rounded essay writer. Though the Western canon notably does not focus on women writers and characters often, I was surprised and grateful for the opportunities that professors created for us to discuss issues that arose with female characters in detail, including Sappho's critical reception; consent and violation in Ovid; feminine tropes in The Odyssey; Clytemnestra's grief in Agamemnon, etc.
The seminar style really makes this class. I could engage deeply with the texts because of the small class setting.

Like all DS courses, I wish that some of the lecturers were better prepared, or structured their lectures in a way that was more insightful or conducive to learning. I sometimes felt that they were very all over the place and not cohesive.
Yes, it's a great survey of classical Western literature and will help you gain context for other books and courses
Yes. I think the professor's dedication to reasonable arguments was helpful because it forced me to be more careful when making assumptions about the text.
Yes - if you want to gain a broad overview of the Western Canon. If you prefer close-reading short sections of text and delving deeply into a single text, other courses may be better for you.
Yes I would.  Literature is a great way to decompress from some of the rigor with which the other DS classes approach material.
Not really, it's a lot of work.
Yes. Canonical knowledge is essential. You will learn in this course. You will learn a lot about what literature was and is, and the intersection of those two.
Yes  the literature is engaging and valuable.

I would recommend Directed Studies to other students (pending, of course, an interest in the humanities). It was obvious that this course and program was well-curated to develop more efficient, effective readers, strong writers, and well-rounded people. It is amazing how much more I understand about the world around me after a semester in Directed Studies, whether it be New Yorker articles or the literature I read in my spare time. The texts we read are influential for a reason and this program is truly the best way to encounter them.
I would. Professor Slanski is awesome and I have very much enjoyed the DS curriculum.
Yes! Loved being able to build a foundation of knowledge of literature to inform my reading of modern literature.
